contentrichtext.text: {{one source|date=February 2012}} {{no footnotes|date=February 2012}} '''Richard Mant''' (February 12, 1776 – 1848) was an [[England|English]] churchman and writer. ==Life== He was born at [[Southampton, England|Southampton]], a grandson of the noted clerical antiquary Bingham, and educated at [[Winchester College]] and at [[Trinity College, Oxford]]. He was elected fellow of [[Oriel College, Oxford|Oriel]] in 1798, and afterwards took orders, holding a curacy at Southampton in 1802. In 1808 he published ''The Simpliciad'', this satirical poem was addressed in verse to [[William Wordsworth]], [[Robert Southey]] and [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]], with notes relating to his parodies and allusions to the originals. He was appointed to the vicarage of [[Coggeshall]], [[Essex, England|Essex]] in (1810) and in 1811 he became [[Bampton Lecturer]]. In 1816 was made rector of St Botolph's, and in 1820 became [[Bishop of Killaloe and Kilfenora]], ([[Ireland]]). In 1823 he was [[Translation (ecclesiastical)|translated]] to [[Bishop of Down and Connor|Down and Connor]], and from 1842 he became the [[Bishop of Down, Connor and Dromore]] when the two dioceses united. ==Works== In collaboration with the Reverend [[s:D'Oyly, George (DNB00)|''George D'Oyly'']], Mant wrote a commentary on the whole [[Bible]]. Other works by him include the [http://archive.org/details/bookofpsalmsinen00mant ''Psalms in an English Metrical Version''] (1842) and a ''History of the Church of Ireland'' (1839–1841; 2 vols.). His [[Bampton Lectures]] [http://archive.org/details/cu31924029180730 ''An Appeal to the Gospel''] were published in 1812. His [http://archive.org/details/ancienthymnstrf01unkngoog ''Ancient Hymns from the Roman Breviary''] (1837) was one of the earliest collections of translated Latin hymnody in English. {{1911}} ==References== * ''The Simpliciad'': 1808 (Revolution and Romanticism, 1789–1834) Publisher: Woodstock Books Inc.
